title: 1985-D
statement: D. Manhattan Circletime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputGiven a $$$n$$$ by $$$m$$$ grid consisting of '.' and '#' characters, there exists a whole manhattan circle on the grid. The top left corner of the grid has coordinates $$$(1,1)$$$, and the bottom right corner has coordinates $$$(n, m)$$$.Point ($$$a, b$$$) belongs to the manhattan circle centered at ($$$h, k$$$) if $$$|h - a| + |k - b| < r$$$, where $$$r$$$ is a positive constant.On the grid, the set of points that are part of the manhattan circle is marked as '#'. Find the coordinates of the center of the circle.InputThe first line contains $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 1000$$$)  — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\cdot m \\leq 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the height and width of the grid, respectively.The next $$$n$$$ lines contains $$$m$$$ characters '.' or '#'. If the character is '#', then the point is part of the manhattan circle.It is guaranteed the sum of $$$n \\cdot m$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$, and there is a whole manhattan circle on the grid.OutputFor each test case, output the two integers, the coordinates of the center of the circle.ExampleInput65 5............#............5 5..#...###.#####.###...#..5 6.............#....###....#....1 1#5 6...#....###..#####..###....#..2 10.............#......Output3 3 3 3 4 2 1 1 3 4 2 4

processed.result:
You are given a grid of size $n \times m$ filled with '.' and '#' characters.  The '#' characters form a complete Manhattan circle within the grid. The top-left corner of the grid is at coordinates $(1,1)$ and the bottom-right corner is at $(n,m)$.

A point $(a,b)$ is part of the Manhattan circle centered at $(h,k)$ if  $|h-a| + |k-b| < r$, where $r$ is a positive constant.

Your task is to find the coordinates $(h,k)$ of the center of the Manhattan circle.

**Input:**

* The first line contains $t$ ($1 \le t \le 1000$) - the number of test cases.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains $n$ and $m$ ($1 \le n \cdot m \le 2 \cdot 10^5$) - the height and width of the grid.
    * The next $n$ lines contain $m$ characters, '.' or '#'. '#' represents a point on the circle.

**Output:**

For each test case, output two integers, the coordinates $(h,k)$ of the circle's center.

You are given a grid of dots and hashes.  Find the center of the circle that contains all the hashes.  The circle is a "Manhattan circle" which means the distance between points is calculated by adding the absolute difference of their x-coordinates and y-coordinates.
